conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with two hemispheres A and B with masses m and 2m respectively.
Hemisphere B is smooth, and there's friction between hemisphere A and the left wall.
The line connecting the centers of the two balls makes a 30-degree angle with the horizontal direction towards A.
The two balls are just about to slide, and the maximum static friction is equal to the sliding friction force.
Need to find the dynamic friction coefficient between hemisphere A and the left wall.
There are two hemispheres between two vertical walls. Hemisphere A is on the left, and hemisphere B is on the right.
The line connecting the centers of A and B makes a 130-degree angle in the image.
Assume the angle is 30 degrees unless told otherwise.
Since B is smooth, there's no friction between A and B.
Hemisphere A has friction with the left wall.
Need to draw free-body diagrams for both A and B to understand the forces acting on them.
Hemisphere B has a mass of 2m, so its weight is 2mg downward.
There must be normal forces from A and the right wall acting on B.
Define N_AB as normal force from A on B, N_Bwall as normal force from the right wall on B, F_fric_A as friction force between A and the left wall, and N_Awall as normal force from the left wall on A.
Hemisphere A has a mass of m, so its weight is mg downward.
There's a normal force from B on A (which is N_AB).
Consider the forces in both the horizontal and vertical directions for both A and B.
For hemisphere B, in the vertical direction, the weight is 2mg downward.
Since the line connecting A and B is at 30 degrees to the horizontal, the normal force between A and B will have both vertical and horizontal components.
Resolve N_AB into horizontal and vertical components: Horizontal component of N_AB is N_AB * cos(30°), Vertical component of N_AB is N_AB * sin(30°).
Normal force from the right wall is horizontal, perpendicular to the wall.
